presentation.title: Subsistence fisheries in Madagascar
presentation.runninghead: Values of fish to coastal populations in Madagascar.
presentation.description: The values resulting from subsistence fishing, particularly in poor coastal communities, quantified through the analysis of potential sources of fish, demand for and simulation of actual access to fisheries.

page.name: Subsistence fishing assessment
page.title: Introduction
page.description:
This storyline demonstrates the use of ARIES in quantifying specific values of fisheries resources to coastal populations that depend on these resources as critical sources of nutrition and protein.
Subsistence harvesting of ecosystem goods is critical in the developing world as well as in developed nations. Such ecosystem goods have been termed the "GDP of the poor," since they provide employment and livelihoods for many of the worldâ€™s poor while not being monetized in traditional economic accounts like GDP. Societal dependence on subsistence fisheries, combined with overfishing, pollution, and climate change, adds to the importance of sustainably managing aquatic resources.
With the support of the "UNEP World Conservation Monitoring Centre":http://www.unep-wcmc.org we have developed this storyline for Madagascar, chosen because of its high rate of poverty, dependence on fisheries as a key protein source in rural communities, and prevalent deforestation-driven sedimentation and erosion, which impact its coastal and marine systems.
page.see-also: The fisheries section of the ARIES web site
page.credits: Funding: UNEP World Conservation Monitoring Centre.

page.name: Proximity
page.title: Distance To coast
page.description: Populations that live in coastal areas in developing nations often depend on local fisheries for their daily subsistence. This analysis was therefore restricted to populations living near the coast. In this storyline, we used a coastal buffer of 5km, assuming that the likely beneficiaries of subsistence fisheries need to be able to reach the coast by walking. Distance to the coast was categorized in three classes of distance, and this variable entered the probabilistic calculation to identify actual use of subsistence fisheries.
page.see-also: The fisheries section of the ARIES web site
page.credits:
Data provided by: Foiben-Taosarintanin'i Madagasikara
Funding: UNEP World Conservation Monitoring Centre.

page.name: Population
page.title: Population density
page.description: To estimate demand for subsistence fisheries, population density data were used as a first step to determine demand levels. These data were intersected with the coastal proximity layer to estimate how many people are likely to depend on subsistence fisheries in an area. This map shows population density for all of Madagascar, and is used as an input in the probabilistic demand calculations.
page.see-also: The fisheries section of the ARIES web site
page.credits:
Data provided by: Oak Ridge National Laboratories
Funding: UNEP World Conservation Monitoring Centre.

page.name: Poverty
page.title: Poverty level
page.description: People are more likely to rely on fisheries for subsistence use when they lack other sources of nutrition. Poverty rates estimated by Elvidge et al. (2009) were used as part of the probabilistic determination of the degree of subsistence fisheries use. The map shows reclassified poverty rates for the whole region of interest.
page.see-also:
Elvidge, C.D., P.S. Sutton, K.E. Baugh, B.T. Tuttle, A.T. Howard, E.H. Erwin, B. Bhaduri, and E. Bright. 2009. A global poverty map derived from satellite data. Computers and Geosciences 35 (8): 1652-1660.
The fisheries section of the ARIES web site
page.credits:
Data provided by: Elvidge et al., 2009
Funding: UNEP World Conservation Monitoring Centre.

page.name: Subsistence demand
page.title: Subsistence demand
page.description:
h1. Subsistence fishery demand
This map shows the result of a probabilistic models estimating the need for fish to support the livelihoods of coastal populations. Darker blues indicate greater need - among poorer populations that live closer to the coast. This map is a probabilistic one, illustrating the probability of needing fish for subsistence. You can click on the map and visualize the probability distribution in each point. The flow model you will see later determines the actual value of the fish resource, depending on the need, the quality and abundance of the resource, and the ability to access it by walking to the shoreline.
page.see-also: The fisheries section of the ARIES web site
page.credits: Funding: UNEP World Conservation Monitoring Centre.

page.name: Sky emperor
page.title: Sky emperor abundance
page.description:
Now that we have quantified the need for fish, we must model the likely provision of fish. Fish species abundance data are difficult to find. We use data on relative abundances from The Sea Around Us project as a starting point in modeling likely fish availability. We have chosen the three important species for subsistence in Madagascar for which relative abundance data are available. This maps shows relative abundance of _Lethrinus mahsena_ (sky emperor). The numbers here have relative significance, as the actual harvest data are shown later by intersecting with catch data from FAO.
The data have 0.5 degree resolution, so these results are relatively coarse. ARIES can automatically interpolate values based on the resolution of the use and flow models, and will compute the uncertainty related to the interpolation so that no information is lost.
page.see-also:
Lethrinus mahsena on FishBase
The fisheries section of the ARIES web site
page.credits:
Data provided by: Sea Around Us project
Funding: UNEP World Conservation Monitoring Centre.

page.name: Snubnose emperor

The data have 0.5 degree resolution, so these results are relatively coarse. ARIES can automatically interpolate values based on the resolution of the use and flow models, and will compute the uncertainty related to the interpolation so that no information is lost.

page.name: Mangrove snapper
page.title: Mangrove red snapper abundance
page.description:
Now that we have quantified the need for fish, we must model the likely provision of fish. Fish species abundance data are difficult to find. We use data on relative abundances from The Sea Around Us project as a starting point in modeling likely fish availability. We have chosen the three important species for subsistence in Madagascar for which relative abundance data are available. This maps shows relative abundance of _Lutjanus argentimaculatus_ (mangrove red snapper). The numbers here have relative significance, as the actual harvest data are shown later by intersecting with catch data from FAO.
The data have 0.5 degree resolution, so these results are relatively coarse. ARIES can automatically interpolate values based on the resolution of the use and flow models, and will compute the uncertainty related to the interpolation so that no information is lost.

page.name: Total harvest
page.title: Total potential subsistence harvest
page.description:
Subsistence fisheries provision map

The source of benefits for this storyline is the total amount of potential fish harvestable by coastal populations. Only a small fraction of this potential is usable by the beneficiaries; the computation of the actual use is shown later in the flow model output.

Historical catch data are published by the FAO (2008). These data do not explicitly describe subsistence catch and do not contain catch records specific to any of the species for which we have relative abundance data. Despite these limitations, we can use assumptions to estimate the likely supply or source value for the three species of interest. These assumptions can be adjusted should more refined fisheries information become available. This map shows estimated source values for the mangrove red snapper (Lutjanus argentimaculatus). A similar process was used to estimate source values for the other species considered. The sum of these maps constitutes our source model.

Historical catch data from The Sea Around Us Project shows that 71.6% of the total catch for Madagascar from 1950-2004 is "non-identified marine pelagic fishes." In 2005, Madagascar produced 138,477 tonnes of fish from capture fisheries, of which 77,636 tonnes were for commodity trade and production. Another 72,300 tonnes were taken by traditional fishermen; however, this catch is not necessarily mutually exclusive of the commodity sector. Subtracting the commodity catch from the total catch leaves 60,841 tonnes of fish which we assume goes toward local consumption. Assuming 71.6% of the locally consumed fish are "non-identified marine pelagic fishes," these account for 43,562 tonnes. Assuming that each of the fish species for which we have distribution data accounted for 20% of that total, this would give 8,712 tonnes of fish caught for each of these species. We then divide the total catch for each species according to their relative abundance along the Madagascar coast in order to produce a map of subsistence fish production for each species under the above assumptions (Equation 1). A similar equation holds for subsistence fisheries use (Equation 2).

(1) S = a1S1 + a2S2 + a3S3 + â€¦ + anSn
(2) D = a1S1 + a2S2 + a3S3 + â€¦ + anSn

Where

S
the total source or supply of subsistence fisheries (kg)
D
the total demand for subsistence fisheries (kg)
an
the percentage of the total demand met with species n
Sn
the total mass of species n caught (kg)

These simplifying assumptions reflect limited data for supply and demand in Madagascarâ€™s subsistence fishery and the distribution of valuable species. Given better data and/or expert knowledge of the relative use of different species, we can easily adjust the model coefficients to more accurately quantify human dependence on local subsistence fisheries in Madagascar or elsewhere.
page.see-also:
FAO fishery statistical collections
The fisheries section of the ARIES web site
page.credits:
Data provided by: FAO 2008
Funding: UNEP World Conservation Monitoring Centre.

page.name: Paths
page.title: Pathways to shore
page.description:
We have computed both the amount of need (demand) and the amount of potential provision (supply) of fish. The last step of the analysis is to model the flow of this ecosystem service to the beneficiaries we have identified, which allows us to understand the actual value of this resource used in this context, as well as pointing out areas of unmet demand and inefficiencies in the use of the resource.
The subsistence fisheries flow model shows the expected spatial dependence of specific fisheries users on particular fisheries areas. Users are assumed to move from a point of origin (their homes) to an oceanic fishery, harvest fish, and return to their homes, where fish are consumed, via road or path networks.
This map shows the paths and road network that determines the accessibility of the locations where fish are provided. The flow model moves a given quantity of fish (in kg) from the ocean to areas of demand along these roads or paths. Each coastal ocean point has an estimated potential source of fish, computed in the source or supply model. Each point on land has an estimated potential use for oceanic fish, computed in our demand model.
We assume that the use of oceanic subsistence fisheries is greatest close to the coast and declines relatively quickly moving inland. We model this distance decay as a Gaussian curve with high subsistence use within 1 km of the coast, steep decline at distances of 2-3 km of the coast, and slowly declining subsistence use out to a distance of 5 km of the coast.
page.see-also: The fisheries section of the ARIES web site
page.credits:
Data provided by: Madagascar infrastructure database (BD500)
Funding: UNEP World Conservation Monitoring Centre.

page.name: Fish flow
page.title: Actual subsistence fish flow
page.description:
The *actual flow density* map shows the flow paths that deliver actual services to humans. These are selected from the total flow density to only show these flow paths that are not depleted by sinks and actually reach users.
This map shows the movement of fish from areas where they are caught to communities where they are consumed, based on transportation networks, supply, demand, and distance decay.
page.see-also: The fisheries section of the ARIES web site
page.credits: Funding: UNEP World Conservation Monitoring Centre.

page.name: Actual value
page.title: Actually utilized subsistence fish
page.description:
The *actual source map* shows the portion of the source map that is actually relevant to the provision of a service after accounting for flow dynamics. This map shows the part of the source or supply region that is actually providing benefits to the users.
In this model, the actual use map is the quantity of fish harvested for subsistence use.
page.see-also: The fisheries section of the ARIES web site
page.credits: Funding: UNEP World Conservation Monitoring Centre.

page.name: Satisfied need
page.title: Satisfied subsistence fish demand
page.description:
The *actual use map* represents the portion of the demand map or potential users whose needs have been satisfied by the flow of services, taking into account the availability of the resource, and flow dynamics.
In this model, the map shows the portion of demand for fish satisfied by flows of fish to people from a fishery.
page.see-also: The fisheries section of the ARIES web site
page.credits: Funding: UNEP World Conservation Monitoring Centre.

page.name: Unused fish
page.title: Unutilized subsistence fish
page.description:
The *inaccessible source map* shows the part of the source value that cannot deliver a service carrier to humans based on the flow routes and the source and user locations.
In this case, the map showes fisheries that are not used due to lack of proximity or pathways to users. This value may also be positive if some of the fish supply remains after all user demand is satiatied.
page.see-also: The fisheries section of the ARIES web site
page.credits: Funding: UNEP World Conservation Monitoring Centre.

page.name: Unmet need
page.title: Unsatisfied subsistence fish demand
page.description:
The *inaccessible use map* shows the potential users that cannot receive a service carrier due to flow routes and the source and user locations. For provisioning services, this corresponds to value produced by the environment but that cannot be reached by users. For preventive services, it corresponds to damage that could have been inflicted on users but is not due to a lack of flow connections to users.
This map shows the portion of demand for fish not satisfied due to inadequate size of the fishery or a lack of proximity to a fishery. If this is zero, some unutilized fish may be a result of a true surplus and not just a lack of proximity. If this is greater than zero, there is no surplus within range.
page.see-also: The fisheries section of the ARIES web site
page.credits: Funding: UNEP World Conservation Monitoring Centre.
